title: 104_hr2624
content: The Act is titled the "American Samoa Study Commission Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that the islands of Tutuila and Manua, along with other islands of American Samoa, were ceded to the United States by treaties in 1900 and 1904. American Samoa's political status as a territory of the United States needs a comprehensive study to clarify its relationship compared to other territories. The economic and social needs of American Samoa are significantly impacted by its political status and relationship with the United States. Additionally, there is a need for a comprehensive study on Swains Island. The "American Samoa Study Commission" is established to address the economic and social needs of American Samoa and conduct a comprehensive study on Swains Island. The Commission is tasked with studying American Samoa's historical and present political status and relationship with the United States, including events leading to cession and treaties affecting its status. It will also determine the nature of American Samoa's relationship compared to other arrangements and assess trust obligations created by treaties of cession. The Commission is responsible for studying American Samoa's political status and relationship with the United States, including trust obligations. It will determine if a single document is needed to define this relationship and assess its impact on the economic and social needs of American Samoa and its residents. The Commission will also consult with American Samoans in carrying out its duties. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 5 members appointed by different authorities, with each member serving for the life of the Commission. Members shall receive $150 per day, subject to availability of funds. Members of the Commission are entitled to $150 per day for their duties, with travel expenses covered. Full-time federal employees on the Commission cannot receive additional compensation. A quorum consists of 3 members, and the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson positions are established. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission are elected by the members. The Secretary of the Interior must call the initial meeting within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and subsequent meetings can be called by the Chairperson or a majority of the members. SEC. 6. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, who can appoint staff and set their pay. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Chairperson can also procure temporary experts and consultants. The Commission can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding $150 per day. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services upon request. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Required hearings must be conducted in Tutuila, Ofu, Olosega, and Tau, with additional hearings in locations with significant American Samoan populations. Public notice of hearings must be provided. The Commission may hold hearings in various locations to obtain public participation and may delegate authority to members or agents to take necessary actions. The Commission can also request official data from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission can hold hearings in different locations for public participation and delegate authority. It can also request official data from Federal agencies. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other Federal agencies, except for information prohibited by law. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission is required to prepare and publish a draft report within one year of the enactment of the Act, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The report will be distributed to relevant agencies and made available to the public upon request. Comments will be solicited from agencies and individuals who receive the report. A final report must be published within nine months of the initial report. The Commission must submit a final report to the President and Congress, including findings, recommendations for legislative and administrative actions, and all written comments received. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The term "American Samoan" is defined as "native American Samoan" in Public Law 100-571. The term "Commission" refers to the American Samoa Study Commission. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for implementing this Act are authorized to be appropriated. SEC. 11. TERMINATION. The Commission will end within 60 days after submitting its final report.
